chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Management
chapter.summary: Covers the management of people with suspected temporomandibular disorders in primary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 12 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with a suspected temporomandibular disorder?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• If a serious or life-threatening condition is suspected that may mimic a temporomandibular disorder (TMD), following an assessment for Red flags, manage appropriately using clinical judgement.
  • Arrange referral to oral medicine or oral and maxillofacial surgery for specialist investigations and management, depending on clinical judgement, if a person has:
    • A history of trauma or fracture to the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) complex.
    • Markedly limited mouth opening (closed lock) suggesting disc displacement without reduction.
  • For all other people with a suspected TMD, encourage early self-management to help control symptoms and limit functional impairment:
    • Reassure that the condition is usually non-progressive, and that symptoms may fluctuate, but should improve.
    • Eat a soft diet and rest the jaw if there is acute pain.
    • Try to avoid parafunctional activities that may exacerbate symptoms, such as wide yawning, teeth grinding or jaw clenching, chewing gum or pencils, and nail biting.
    • Consider simple analgesia for short-term use, such as paracetamol or a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). For prescribing information, see the CKS topics on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain and NSAIDs - prescribing issues.
    • Consider local measures for pain relief, such as applying covered ice or a warm flannel or heat pad, or massaging affected muscles.
    • Try to identify sources of stress, and give advice on relaxation techniques, setting realistic targets, pacing activities, and getting social support where available. Manage any co-morbid depression. See the CKS topics on Generalized anxiety disorder and Depression for more information.
    • Give advice on sleep hygiene. See the CKS topic on Insomnia for more information.
  • Provide sources of information and advice, such as:
    • The NHS patient information leaflet Temporomandibular disorder.
    • The British Association of Oral Surgeons leaflet Temporomandibular (jaw) joint problems.
    • The Orofacial Pain Project, which is a non-profit organisation that provides education resources for people with chronic pain in the head, face, and mouth. It has a patient leaflet Temporomandibular disorders and website (available at www.orofacialpain.org.uk).
    • The European Academy of Craniomandibular Disorders patient information leaflet Craniomandibular disorders.
  • Consider whether additional drug treatment may be helpful for adults:
    • If symptoms are acute and severe, consider prescribing a short course of a low-dose benzodiazepine such as diazepam 2 mg up to three times daily, for a maximum of 2 weeks. For prescribing information, see the section on Diazepam in Prescribing information.
    • If there is chronic pain, consider prescribing a neuropathic analgesic such as amitriptyline (off-label) or gabapentin (off-label). For prescribing information, see the CKS topic on Neuropathic pain - drug treatment.
  • Consider referral to additional specialists if appropriate, such as to:
    • A dentist, if there is poor dental health, suspected malocclusion or dental pathology, or for consideration of an occlusal splint (usually worn at night; particularly useful for people who grind or clench their teeth). Note: referral to the local dental hospital or oral and maxillofacial surgery department may be appropriate depending on the person's ability to pay for dental treatment.
    • Psychology services for cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT), if there is marked psychological distress associated with symptoms, or to help with pain-related anxiety.
    • Physiotherapy for advice on passive jaw stretching exercises, posture training, and massage or acupuncture to help relax muscle spasm, if available.

  • Arrange referral to oral medicine; oral and maxillofacial surgery; ear, nose, and throat (ENT) surgery; neurology; or a multidisciplinary pain clinic for specialist investigations and management, depending on clinical judgement, if a person has:

    • Chronic TMD symptoms lasting for more than 3 months.

    • Persistent or worsening symptoms despite primary care treatment.
    • An uncertain diagnosis.
    • Marked psychological distress associated with symptoms and/or occlusal preoccupation (persistent hyperawareness or hypervigilance of their bite).
    • Unexplained persistent pain or chronic widespread pain.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Specialist investigations and management
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Specialist investigations and management may be considered for people with significant functional impairment of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ), and/or an intra-articular disorder such as anterior disc displacement or degenerative joint disease.

  • Investigations include:
    • Plain or panoramic X-rays to identify dental pathology, fractures, dislocations, or severe degenerative joint disease.
    • CT to assess for degenerative joint disease or subluxation of the TMJ.
    • MRI to assess for TMJ disc displacement, subluxation, arthrosis, or synovial proliferation.
  • Management options include:
    • Botulinum toxin injection into the masseter and temporalis muscles of mastication.
    • Intra-articular injection of sodium hyaluronate or corticosteroid preparations for degenerative joint disease.
    • Surgery options include:
      • Arthrocentesis or arthroscopy for non-myogenous temporomandibular disorders (TMDs) with significant functional impairment.
      • Arthroplasty for more severe TMJ degeneration.
      • Eminectomy or eminoplasty for recurrent TMJ dislocation.
      • Total prosthetic TMJ replacement for end-stage degenerative disease.
  • The following treatments are not recommended (due to a lack of evidence of benefit):
    • Occlusal adjustment (selective grinding of the tooth enamel to achieve a more harmonious bite).
    • Orthodontics.

[de Souza et al, 2012; Durham et al, 2013; Zakrzewska, 2013; NICE, 2014; Schiffman et al, 2014; Durham et al, 2015; Gauer and Semidey, 2015; Ghurye and McMillan, 2015]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the management of temporomandibular disorders (TMDs) in primary care are largely based on expert opinion in the Royal College of Surgeons' Faculty of Dental Surgery publication Temporomandibular disorders (TMDs): an update and management guidance for primary care from the UK Specialist Interest Group in Orofacial Pain and TMDs (USOT) [Durham et al, 2013], expert opinion in the International RDC/TMD Consortium Network and Orofacial Pain Special Interest Group publication Diagnostic criteria for temporomandibular disorders (DC/TMD) for clinical and research applications: recommendations of the International RDC/TMD Consortium Network and Orofacial Pain Special Interest Group [Schiffman et al, 2014], and expert opinion in review articles on TMDs [Durham et al, 2015; Gauer and Semidey, 2015; Ghurye and McMillan, 2015] and review articles on the differential diagnosis of facial pain [Zakrzewska, 2013].

Managing red flags appropriately
  • This recommendation is pragmatic based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Arranging specialist referral if there is a history of trauma or fracture, or suspected disc displacement without reduction
  • These recommendations are based on expert opinion in the Royal College of Surgeons' Faculty of Dental Surgery publication [Durham et al, 2013] and expert opinion in review articles on TMDs [Durham et al, 2015; Gauer and Semidey, 2015; Ghurye and McMillan, 2015].
  • The recommendation on specialist referral if the person has suspected disc displacement without reduction is also based on expert opinion from previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.
Offering patient education and self-management advice
  • These recommendations are based on expert opinion in the Royal College of Surgeons' Faculty of Dental Surgery publication that early, non-invasive treatments may have a 68–95% success rate across people with all subtypes of TMDs [Durham et al, 2013]. This is reinforced by expert opinion in a US review article on TMDs that most people's symptoms improve with a combination of non-invasive treatments [Gauer and Semidey, 2015].
  • Expert opinion in the International RDC/TMD Consortium Network and Orofacial Pain Special Interest Group publication states that the longer TMD pain persists, the greater the risk of cognitive, psychosocial, and behavioural sequelae, which can increase pain sensitivity, increase the likelihood of persistent pain, and reduce the likely benefits from non-invasive treatments [Schiffman et al, 2014]. This is supported by expert opinion in review articles that reversible, conservative treatments should be tried first-line, and that self-management improves prognosis [Zakrzewska, 2013; Durham et al, 2015; Ghurye and McMillan, 2015].
  • The recommendation on eating a soft diet and resting the jaw if there is an acute exacerbation of symptoms is based on expert opinion in the Royal College of Surgeons' Faculty of Dental Surgery publication [Durham et al, 2013] and a review article on the differential diagnosis of facial pain [Zakrzewska, 2013].
  • The recommendation on offering simple analgesia for the initial acute management of TMD symptoms is based on expert opinion in the Royal College of Surgeons' Faculty of Dental Surgery publication [Durham et al, 2013] and expert opinion in review articles on TMDs [Durham et al, 2015; Gauer and Semidey, 2015; Ghurye and McMillan, 2015].
  • The recommendation on considering local pain relief with the application of cold, heat, or massage to affected areas is based on expert opinion in a review article [Durham et al, 2015].
  • The recommendations on treating co-morbid anxiety, depression, and insomnia are based on the fact that these conditions together with pain catastrophising, a preoccupation with somatic symptoms, and poor coping skills may predispose a person with an acute TMD to developing chronic pain [Durham et al, 2015; Gauer and Semidey, 2015; Ghurye and McMillan, 2015].
Prescribing additional drug treatments
  • The recommendations to consider prescribing a short course of a benzodiazepine such as diazepam for acute, severe TMD pain is based on limited evidence that it may provide relief of muscle spasm caused by an acute exacerbation of myofascial pain with limited mouth opening, for example following dental intervention [Durham et al, 2013; Gauer and Semidey, 2015; Ghurye and McMillan, 2015]. Expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic also supported the short-term use of benzodiazepines for acute TMD pain. 
  • The recommendation to consider prescribing additional neuropathic analgesics such as amitriptyline (off-label) and gabapentin (off-label) to treat chronic TMD-related pain is based on limited evidence [Durham et al, 2013], which is often extrapolated from use of these agents for other chronic pain conditions [Zakrzewska, 2013; Gauer and Semidey, 2015; Ghurye and McMillan, 2015].
  • A Cochrane systematic review of drug treatments for people with chronic TMD-related pain (search date to August 2010) found 11 small randomized controlled trials (n = 496) of variable quality with significant heterogeneity among the studies. If found insufficient evidence to support or not support the use of analgesics (including nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs), benzodiazepines (including diazepam), and anticonvulsants (gabapentin) [Mujakperuo et al, 2010]. 
Considering referral to additional specialists
  • The recommendation on referral to a dentist to exclude any dental pathology is based on expert opinion in review articles on TMDs [Durham et al, 2015; Ghurye and McMillan, 2015] and the expert opinion of previous external reviewers of this CKS topic. The use of occlusal splints are designed to alleviate degenerative forces placed on the temporomandibular joint (TMJ), articular disc, and teeth [Gauer and Semidey, 2015], and they may provide biofeedback, especially if the person has parafunctional activities and is at risk of toothwear or periodontal trauma [Durham et al, 2013; Durham et al, 2015]. CKS notes, however, that the use of occlusal splints is controversial in the literature, and there is a lack of evidence on the role of malocclusion in the development of TMDs, and uncertainty about the exact mechanism for any benefits. Some commentators suggest that splint therapy may actually increase occlusal preoccupation (hypervigilance) and soft splints may increase parafunctional activity [Ghurye and McMillan, 2015].
  • The recommendation on referral for cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) and anxiety management is based on the fact that it may help chronic pain management and help the person identify factors which may precipitate or exacerbate TMD symptoms [Durham et al, 2015; Gauer and Semidey, 2015]. Most people with TMD-related pain get some benefit from CBT, and people with chronic TMD pain may have long-term improvements in pain intensity, depression, and daily functioning and activities [Durham et al, 2013].
  • The recommendation on referral to physiotherapy is based on limited evidence that massage or targeted exercises may provide short-term relief for acute TMD symptoms and improve joint function [Durham et al, 2013; Durham et al, 2015]. In addition, acupuncture (if available) may reduce myofascial pain intensity and masseteric tenderness by treating muscle trigger points [Durham et al, 2013; Durham et al, 2015; Gauer and Semidey, 2015; Ghurye and McMillan, 2015], but it may have limited long-term benefits [Zakrzewska, 2013].
Arranging specialist referral to oral medicine or oral and maxillofacial surgery; ear, nose, and throat surgery; neurology; or a multidisciplinary pain clinic
  • These recommendations are based on expert opinion in the Royal College of Surgeons' Faculty of Dental Surgery publication [Durham et al, 2013] and expert opinion in review articles on TMDs [Durham et al, 2015; Gauer and Semidey, 2015; Ghurye and McMillan, 2015].
  • The recommendation on specialist referral if the diagnosis is uncertain is also based on expert opinion from previous external reviewers of this CKS topic.
  • The recommendation on referral to a pain clinic is based on expert opinion in review articles that people with refractory chronic and/or widespread complex pain may need specialist multidisciplinary team management [Durham et al, 2013; Zakrzewska, 2013; Durham et al, 2015; Ghurye and McMillan, 2015].
